Sinnhaftigkeit von IgG-Bestimmungen bei chronischen gastrointestinalen Beschwerden?
authors: A. Feser; Norbert Krauß; Vera Mahler
abstract: A 23-year-old patient has suffered from meteorism and occasional diarrhea for 8 years. Specific IgG antibodies directed towards multiple foods had been determined elsewhere. A concordant elimination diet had led to loss of body weight of 10 kg (remaining body weight 40 kg) without any improvement of the symptoms. At the time of first presentation in our Allergy Unit, a concise allergological work-up had not been performed. The skin prick testing of inhalant allergens, foods, spices, flour, preservatives and latex-associated foods showed 3+-positive reactions to grass pollen, rye pollen, dermatophagoides pteronyssinus, pepper, wheat flour and rye flour; 2+-positive reactions to curry, sodium proprionate and sorbic acid. Determination of specific IgE antibodies to rye flour, wheat flour, pepper and curry were negative, as well as serology for celiac disease. After dramatic weight loss due to elimination diet of 87 foods according to IgG antibodies identified elsewhere, positive prick test results were found to the above mentioned foods and food additives (pepper, wheat- and rye flour, curry as well as sodium proprionate and sorbic acid). A clinically relevant IgE-mediated allergy could be ruled out by an elimination diet to these positive tested foods that did not lead to any improvement of the clinical symptoms. A double-blind placebo-controlled food challenge (DBPCFC) to wheat and rye flour was refused by the patient. A Pillcam endoscopy revealed an inflammatory alteration of the mucous membran of the terminal ileum. Due to a suspected early stage of Crohn's disease, a coloscopy and a double-ballon endoscopy is scheduled. As in the presented case, determination of IgG antibodies raised against foods is not a feasible measure for diagnosis of gastrointestinal disorders and may lead to a significant delay in correct diagnosis and therapy of the underlying disease.

title: Primär chronischer Verlauf einer exogen-allergischen Alveolitis durch Diisozyanate bei einer Sekretärin infolge indirekter Exposition
authors: Jens Schreiber; J. Knolle; S. Heerdt; K. Schulz; Christian Schreiber; J. Sennekamp; R. Merget

title: Levocetirizin vs. Cetirizin: Eine evidenzbasierte Differenzierung anhand der Pharmakologie und Klinik
abstract: Levocetirizine is developed from cetirizine and belongs to the group of antihistamines with high and selective receptor binding. The pharmacological properties of cetirizine and levocetirizine are different, as are the results in wheal-and-flare studies. Levocetirizine furthermore was the first antihistamine to demonstrate a long-term efficacy over 6-month treatment period on symptoms, quality of life, comorbidity and pharmacoeconomics. This study shows that the treatment of persistent allergic rhinitis, which is the most severe form of rhinitis, by levocetirizine makes medically and economically sense.

title: Allergische Rhinitis auf die Zierpflanze Philodendron bipennifolium: Nachweis von spezifischem IgE und positive Reaktion auf Provokation mit Blätterextrakt
authors: M.D. Anliker; Ingmar Heijnen; B. Wüthrich
abstract: Philodendron species are popular indoor plants and are not known to elicit immediate-type allergic reactions so far. We report on a 46-year-old female with persistant rhinoconjunctivitis at home, where a Philodendron (Ph.) bipennifolium was present. The skin prick tests with routine inhalant allergens were positive for grass-, rye-, hazel- and ash pollen. A scratch test was positive for Ph. bipennifolium leaves and Ficus benjamina. Specific IgE (CAP-FEIA) was elevated for Ph. bipennifolium, Ph. scandens, Ficus benjamina and natural rubber latex. A nasal provocation (NPT) with fresh extract from Ph. bipennifolium leaves resulted in rhinorrhea, itching of the throat and increased resistance of the nasal airways. This is the first report on immediate-type allergic reaction to Ph. bipennifolium and detection of specific IgE. The clinical relevance was shown by NPT. Philodendron spp. therefore have allergen(s) potent enough to cause allergic disease in an indoor environment.

title: Eotaxin-, Eotaxin-2-, Eotaxin-3- und RANTES-Proteinsynthese bei Polyposis nasi  Korrelation zu Eosinophilie und Ätiologie
authors: Heidi Olze; Ulrike Förster; Torsten Zuberbier; L. Morawietz; Elke Luger
abstract: Background: Tissue eosinophilia is a striking finding in nasal polyposis. CC-chemokines RANTES, eotaxin and eotaxins-2, -3 play an important role in activation and attraction of eosinophils to the site of inflammation. In order to investigate a possible role of eotaxin, eotaxin-2, eotaxin-3 and RANTES in the development of tissue eosinophilia and nasal polyps, this study was performed. Methods: Eosinophilic nasal polyps (non-allergic n = 8, allergic n = 8, ASS-intolerant n = 8) and mucosa of inferior turbinates of 8 controls were obtained during endonasal surgery. Paraffin sections were stained to determine the extent of eosinophilia. Chemokine protein contents (eotaxin, eotaxin-2,-3 and RANTES) of tissue homogenates were measured by ELISA (quantitative Sandwich ELISA). Results: Protein expression of eotaxin, eotaxin-2 and eotaxin-3 was significantly higher in nasal polyps than in controls and there was a significant correlation between the protein values of all 3 eotaxins. The protein levels of all eotaxins were significantly correlated to the amount of eosinophilia. In contrast, RANTES levels did not show significant differences between patients and controls and there was no correlation to the protein levels of the other chemokines or the amount of eosinophilia. The number of eosinophils was significantly higher in polyps ofASS-sensitive patients than in the other patient groups. Polyps of ASS-sensitive patients had significantly higher eotaxin, eotaxin-2, -3 protein levels than non-allergic patients and significantly higher amounts of eotaxin-3 compared with allergic patients. Conclusions: Our findings suggest that all members of the eotaxin family are implicated in the underlying mechanisms ofeosinophilic attraction in eosinophilia-associated nasal polyposis. Simultaneous expression of these CCR3-ligands or reaching a certain concentration threshold could possibly be prerequisites for stronger eosinophil migration.

title: Interview with Alexander Knipper
Diagnostik bei chronischem Husten in der Pädiatrie
abstract: Coughing is the most frequent symptom which prompts children with their families to consult a physician. Coughing lasting longer than 3 4 weeks requires a careful differential diagnosis. Lung sounds and accompanying symptoms such as atopic markers of the skin, stridor, wheezing, rales, dyspnea, pain, consistency and color of the mucus, mouth breathing during the night, dystrophia etc. are important signs that necessitate the initiation of a rational and adequate diagnostic procedure. The scope of laboratory examinations depends on severity and duration of the disease and comprises the patients history, various lung function tests and, if necessary, invasive procedures. During the last years, new non-invasive methods have been developed which support the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis (electrophysiologic examination at the nasal mucosa to evaluate the transepithelial chloride transport, complete mutation analysis of the cystic fibrosis gene), primary ciliary dyskinesia (measuring nasal (NO)) and obstructive sleep apnea (polysomnography). Modern lung function tests for infants based on improved baby plethysmography allow to separate obstructive from restrictive impairments of the lung in a more reliable manner than before.

title: Immunologische Mechanismen der unterschiedlichen allergischen Phänotypen
authors: Maja Zimmermann; Flurina Meiler; M. Akdis; Cezmi A. Akdiş
abstract: The threshold of activation as well as the life span of a cell are tuned by genetic predisposition and environmental instructions. Allergic patients show a difference in T cell activation and peripheral tolerance comparedto healthy individuals as well as a dysregulated balance in T cell subpopulations (like T helper-1(Thl)-, T helper-2(Th2)-, T helper-0 (ThO)- and T-regulatory(Treg)-cells). Defects in apoptosis and peripheral tolerance in T cells define three different allergic phenotypes such as atopic, non-atopic and monoallergic types. Although there are overlaps and redundancies, the clinical outcome can manifest itself as dermatitis, asthma, rhinitis or without a target organ as it can be in venom allergy. Upon allergic recognition, IFN-γ-producing, activated and allergen-specific Th1 cells in the circulation predominantly undergo apoptosis, skewing the immune response towards the surviving Th2 cells. These Th2 cells infiltrate allergic organs and secrete cytokines, which leads to local inflammation. In the atopic dermatitis skin, it has been demostrated that IL-12 and IL-18 upregulate the Th1 cytokine IFN-y and induce both activation and apoptosis of epithelial cells. In the non-atopic form, AICD of Th1 cells and immunedeviation to Th2 cells leading to IgE production is not observed; whereas epithelial apoptosis remains the main tissue injury event in both asthma and atopic dermatitis. On the other hand, in monoallergic diseases, the T cell response is characterized by a shift in balance towards allergen-specific Th2 cells rather than Treg cells.

title: Wiskott-Aldrich-Syndrom (WAS)
authors: Volker Schuster; Torsten Böhler; Christoph A. Klein

title: 22. Allergiesymposium für Kinderärzte
Die Bedeutung von Brennesselpollen im Vergleich zu Beifußpollen für die saisonale allergische Rhinitis im Spätsommer
authors: Oliver Pfaar; B. Hauswald; Karl‐Bernd Hüttenbrink
abstract: Introduction: The success rate of hyposensitization with mugwort pollen allergen in patients with late-onset seasonal allergic rhinitis is about 70%. Based on measurements over the last 3 years in the Dresden area using the Burkard pollen trap, it was found that during the main blossom season of mugwort, the nettle pollen pollution is high as well. With regard to the total amount of measured pollen, nettle pollen amounted to 78% compared to only 7% mugwort pollen. The aim of this study was to demonstrate the clinical relevance of the high nettle pollen exposure for patients with late-onset seasonal allergic rhinitis in the Dresden area. Methods: Thirty-six patients (17 female, 19 male, mean age 29.4 years) with a seasonal late summer allergic rhinitis were examined. All patients were sensitized to mugwort pollen. Radioallergosorbent test (RAST) and skin prick testing (SPT) for nettle pollen were performed on all patients. A nasal provocation test (NPT) with nettle pollen was performed in 17 patients sensitized to nettle pollen. Results of the provocation were investigated through rhinomanometry after 10, 20 and 30 minutes, respectively. Results: Twenty-four of the 36 patients exhibited a positive SPT and RAST for nettle pollen, showing the sensitization to nettle pollen. Of the 17 patients mentioned above, 8 patients had a positive NPT to nettle pollen. Conclusion: Results of this study indicated that a sensitization for mugwort pollen often coincides with sensitization for nettle pollen. The high nettle pollen exposure in the Dresden area is of clinical importance in the diagnosis of patients with late-onset seasonal allergic rhinitis. Therefore, we recommend that testing for nettle pollen (RAST, SPT and NPT) in patients with late summer allergies shall be included into standard diagnostic procedures. Patients with a positive NPT for nettle pollen may also qualify for hyposensitization therapy for nettle pollen.

title: 6. Jenaer Mykologiesymposium
authors: Prof. Dr. P. Elsner; U.-Ch. Hipler

title: Instruktion von Effektor-T-Zellen zur Einwanderung in entzündete Haut
authors: Stefan F. Martin; Jan C. Dudda
abstract: CD8+-cytotoxic T cells play an important, often dominant role as effector cells in chemical or metal ion-induced contact dermatitis. The reason for the dominance of this T cell subset was unclear, especially since reactive chemicals simultaneously generate immunogenic structures for the activation of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells. Now, we have shown in vitro that the dominance of CD8+ T cells is caused by cytolysis of CD4+ T cells via a fas-dependent mechanism. Moreover, it was unknown how the CD8+ T cells differentiate to become tissue-specific effectors which migrate selectively to inflamed skin. Our studies have revealed that activation of naive T cells by tissue-specific dendritic cells in the microenvironment of skin-draining lymphnodes selectively induces the expression of skin-specific migration receptors. We could demonstrate, for the first time, that Langerhans cells induce these migration receptors on T cells in vitro. This identifies a previously unknown role for Langerhans cells which, besides presenting antigens from the skin to T cells in lymph nodes, also direct T cells selectively to the skin for efficient immunedefense or induction of allergy.

title: Die Rolle dendritischer Zellen bei der atopischen Dermatitis
authors: Natalija Novak; Thomas Bieber; Jean‐Pierre Allam
abstract: Atopic dermatitis (AD) presents as a chronic relapsing skin disease with a characteristic phenotype and typically distributed skin lesions, which make the diagnosis of AD very simple and clear-cut. In contrast, the underlying pathophysiological and genetic mechanisms leading to the manifestation of AD are not obvious. Challenged by this puzzle, scientific approaches of the last years have made considerable progress in gaining insights into the complexity of the mechanisms which cause AD. AD is a biphasic inflammatory skin disease characterized by an initial phase predominated by Th2 cytokines which switches into a second and more chronic Thl-dominated eczematous phase. Two different, the high affinity receptor for IgE(FceRI)-bearing dendritic cell subtypes have been identified in the skin of AD patients: FceRI + Langerhans cells (LC) and FceRI + inflammatory dendritic epidermal cells (IDEC). These dendritic cell subtypes are supposed to contribute distinctly to the biphasic nature and the outcome of T cell responses in AD. In contrast, plasmacytoid dendritic cells which have been shown to bear the high affinity receptor for IgE very recently and which play an important role in the defense against viral infections, are nearly absent from the skin lesions of AD patients. In the light of recent developments, a picture emerges that different IgE receptor-bearing DC subtypes in the blood and the skin of AD patients play a pivotal role in the complex pathophysiological network of AD.

title: Erkrankungen durch Metalle und Metalloide
abstract: Poisonings by heavy metals are rare, nowadays. Nevertheless they exist. Some are carcinogenic, such as chromium, nickel, and arsenic. Other metals are harmful to blood such as lead or to kidney (cadmium). The central nervous system may be damaged e.g. by lead or manganese. These and other adverse effects of metals are described as well as the pathologic origin and therapy of intoxication. Furthermore environmental influences on metal content in human blood or urine are described, e.g. uptake of cadmium in smokers, of arsenic and mercury due to fish consumption.

title: Antrag auf Feststellung eines sonstigen Schadens?
Cluster-Immuntherapie bei allergischer Rhinokonjunktivitis und Asthma bronchiale: Sicherheit der Initialtherapie mit Novo-Helisen Depot
authors: Inga Hansen; Karl Hörmann; L. Klimek; J. Kettner; Annemie Narkus
abstract: Background: Specific immunotherapy (SIT) represents the only causal treatment that can be offered to allergic patients apart from allergen avoidance. In classic SIT, gradually increasing dosages of the allergen extract are injected subcutaneously. Several dosage schedules for subcutaneous SIT can be applied. The classic approach involves single injections at each therapy visit. In Cluster-SIT, two to three injections per day of treatment are given once a week during initial treatment. Patients: In this trial, we investigated 46 patients (17 female, 29 male) from 11 - 71 years (40.7 ′ 13 years) with regard to side effects of a Cluster regime during induction treatment with Novo-Helisen Depot. Four patients were treated with two different extracts, so that a total of 50 initial therapies were observed; 19 patients (41%) suffered from bronchial asthma. Results: We performed 34 treatments with mite extracts, eight treatments with grass pollen extracts and eight treatments with tree pollen extracts with 744 injections in total. The total number of enlarged local reactions (≥ grade 1) was 23, or 3.1% of all injections. Of these, 22 (3.0%) were classified as immediate reactions and one (0.1%) was a late-phase reaction. Of all enlarged local reactions, 22 (3.0%) were grade 1 reactions (5 - 8 cm) and one (0.1%) was a grade 2 reaction (8 - 12 cm). Grades 3 and 4 reactions were not observed. Only one systemic reaction was observed (0.1% of all injections). This reaction was a delayed phase reaction grade 1 (urticaria). Grades 2, 3, or 4 reactions did not occur. There were no differences in gender or age regarding the occurence of side effects (all p > 0.05). Conclusions: Frequency and severity of adverse side effects in Cluster-SIT with Novo-Helisen Depot show an excellent tolerability corresponding to the occurrence of side-effects with other dosage schedules.

title: Typ-I-Sensibilisierung gegenüber Ranitidin
authors: G. Bens; Markus Herrmann; Ulrich Hübner; Jörg Reichrath; Walter Herrmann; Wolfgang Tilgen; Peter Koch
abstract: Ranitidine is an H 2 -receptor antagonist which is generally well tolerated. Since the 1970s, it is used for the treatment of peptic ulcers, esophageal reflux, and Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. In dermatology, ranitidine is recommended as a second-line therapy for chronic urticaria that is not responsive to anti-H 1 monotherapy. We report the case of a 45-year-old woman who presented with urticaria, facial edema and dyspnea after simultaneous ingestion of Sostril (ranitidine) tablets and diclofenac. Scratch testing with Sostril (ranitidine) resulted in a strongly positive reaction in this patient whereas the same test remained negative in a control patient. The scratch test as well as an oral challenge with diclofenac were negative. Because of anaphylactic risk, ranitidine was not tested by oral challenge. A basophil degranulation test was carried out with the suspected drug Sostril, with pure ranitidine, and separately with each constituent of Sostril tablets (microcristalline cellulose, magnesium stearate, hypomellose, titane dioxyd and triacetine) in different concentrations. Significant basophil activation was detected only in aliquots with Sostril or with pure ranitidine, whereas stimulation with the different nonactive constituents produced no basophil degranulation. The results of cutaneous scratch test and in vitro basophil degranulation test suggest immediate-type hypersensitivity to ranitidine to be responsible for the anaphylactic reaction in this patient. Diclofenac may have amplified this reaction by nonimmunologic pathways. Considering the extensive use of H 2 -receptor antagonists, real type I hypersensitivities to these molecules remain exceptional with only few well-documented cases in literature.

title: Evaluation des semiquantitativen Westernblots, des CAP-FEIA und des Hauttests bezüglich der Hymenopterengiftallergie im Hinblick auf eine Hyposensibilisierungsbehandlung
abstract: The diagnosis of stinging insect allergy is based upon history, skin test and the detection of specific (s)IgE and IgG4 to the hymenoptera venoms. However, in vivo- and in vitro diagnostic tests are not 100% specific and sensitive, the stinging insects are sometimes unidentified. The westemblot allows the detection of sIgE and sIgG4 to single allergens and is currently considered as being of mainly supportive value. Therefore, a semiquantitative westemblot method was evaluated with sera of 47 patients with suspected hymenoptera venom allergy. sIgE and sIgG4 were detected using CAP-FEIA (Pharmacia Diagnostics, Freiburg, Germany) and westemblot (DPC Biermann Bad Nauheim, Germany). The intensity of the specific westernblot reactions was determined semi-quantitatively by the software Quantiscan. Before IT, higher concentrations of sIgE and sIgG4 in westernblot were correlated with the severity of the clinical reaction. The correlation factor for the comparison between both in vitro procedures was statistically significant with 0.691 for sIgE and 0.598 for sIgG4, with the calculation being based upon the respective highest peak. Skin test and westernblot showed a correlation for sIgE but not sIgG4. During immunotherapy (IT), sIgE initially increased in 56% of the patients and decreased shortly afterwards, whereas sIgG4 increased during the first 3 years of IT and decreased after more than 2 years after IT discontinuation. According to this investigation, westemblot should be performed at certain intervals during the IT course: before IT, after IT initiation, once during IT, at discontinuation and, additionally, several years after treatment discontinuation.

title: Die Rolle von TGF-b in Immunregulation und Allergie
abstract: Allergic disease are characterized by an unbalanced, overshooting immune response against otherwise harmless allergens. The enduring exposure with environmental allergens leads in the case of asthma to chronic inflammation which, in turn, mobilizes repair processes and irreversible airway remodeling. The cytokine TGF-β as well as activin βA play an important role in the systemic and local processes. However, the role of these cytokines has a Janus-faced character: the immunosuppressive function is clearly welcome, whereas the TGF-β/activin βA promoted airway remodeling is a serious complication of allergic disease. The relative contribution of activin βA and TGF-β is discussed and set into relation of both immunologic and remodeling processes.

title: Professor Dr. phil. nat. Kurt Blaser und das Schweizerische Institut für Allergie- und Asthmaforschung (SIAF)
Klinische, radiologische und histo-pathologische Kriterien zur differential-diagnostischen Abgrenzung der exogen-allergischen Alveolitis von der nicht-spezifischen interstitiellen Pneumonie
authors: Patrick Markart; Andreas Breithecker; R.M. Bohle; Werner Seeger; Albrecht Günther
abstract: The non-specific interstitial pneumonitis (NSIP) is an important differential diagnosis of extrinsic allergic alveolitis (EAA). While the acute course of EAA in spite of similar bronchoalveolar lavage and radiological patterns can be clearly differentiated by serum antibodies and the temporal relationship between antigen contact and clinical symptoms, the chronic course of EAA is difficult to differentiate. Even by open lung biopsy a definite diagnosis can be established in all cases. Due to possible long-term consequences (antigen avoidance) however, an open lung biopsy should be performed in questionable cases.

title: Weltweite Umweltbeobachtung: Das Programm GEOSS und der Nutzen für die Allergologie
abstract: The World Summit on Sustainable Development, Johannesburg 2002 (WSSD), highlighted the urgent need for coordinated observations relating to the state of the earth. A meeting of the Heads of State of the Group of 8 Industralized Countries Summit in June 2003 in Evian, France, affirmed the importance of earth observation as a priority activity. The first Earth Observation Summit convening in Washington, DC, in July 2003, was attended by high-level officials from 33 countries and the European Commission and 21 international organizations involved in earth observations. The Group of Earth Observation developed to the Global Earth Observations System of Systems and has been run by its secretariate at WMO in Geneva since May 2005. The GEOSS 10-year implementation plan, together with a reference document, addresses not only cost effectiveness and technical feasibility, but also institutional feasibility. GEOSS is focused on 9 societal benefit areas where allergy is touched in several of these areas. A summary of airborne ambrosia pollen in Switzerland shows the necessity of boarder crossing of environmental observations because national networks can hardly detect, for example, invasion of new plants and its pollen in a country early enough.

title: Carbamazepin-Hypersensitivitätssyndrom mit Leukopenie und Hepatitis – Kasuistik zweier Fälle
authors: M Bogić; Sanvila Rašković; J. Sojic; Ivan Boričić; Rada Ješić; Lidija Burazer; Vesna Tomić-Spirić; Aleksandra Perić Popadić; Vesna Djuric; Dušica Čeleketić
abstract: Drug hypersensitivity syndrome is a severe form of hypersensitivity to the antiepileptic agent carbamazepine, particularly in presence of visceral and hematological manifestations that must be evidenced and treated in time. Two cases of female patients with carbamazepine-induced hypersensitivity syndrome are reported. Both patients had prominent general complaints (febricity, weakness). The first patient had leukopenia, lymphadenopathy and rash, while the other one had urticaria, angioedema and hepatitis after administration of carbamazepine. Hypersensitivity reactions induced by antiepileptics widely applied in the practice may be severe and life-threatening if blood elements are involved via the immune or nonimmune mechanisms and if they result in hepatitis.

title: Differentialdiagnostik der persistierenden Rhinitis
authors: Matthias Krämer; Christine A. Klemens; Gerd Rasp
abstract: Introduction: This study focused on differential diagnosis of persisting rhinitis, caused by chronic inflammatory nasal and paranasal sinus diseases. This paper aims at describing relevant rhinologic differential diagnoses occurring with more or less similar symptoms. Methods: 9,923 patients complaining about persisting nasal problems were characterized by symptoms and nasal ECP, according to their diagnosis, such as chronic rhinosinusitis, non-allergic rhinitis with eosinophilia syndrome (NARES), nasal polyposis and persisting allergic rhinitis. Atopy screen based on patients history, SX1 (Phadiatop) and total IgE. Non-atopic individuals without sings of a chronic nasal inflammation served as controls. Results: Nasal obstruction was the most bothering symptom for our patients, followed by post-nasal drip and nasal secretion. Post-nasal drip could be extracted as a specific symptom for paranasal sinus involvement. Eosinophils could be demonstrated in all studied chronic inflammatory conditions by nasal ECP with excessive values in NARES patients. NARES was found in 34.9% of all cases with persisting rhinitis. Discussion: Determination of certain in vivo and in vitro parameter enriches the differential diagnosis of persisting rhinitis and constitutes an essential part of modem rhinologic diagnostics, besides nasal endoscopy and X-rays of paranasal sinuses. Although the majority of patients complain about similar symptoms, we could characterize disease-specific impairments. Consequently, diagnostics of persisting rhinitis constitutes a domain for rhinologists.

title: Das nicht-atopische (intrinsische) Ekzem
abstract: Atopic dermatitis (AD) is a chronic relapsing, inflammatory skin disease, caused by a genetic predisposition and a variety of environmental triggers. In most cases, AD is linked to a specific IgE immune response to commoninhalants or food allergens and therefore classified as an atopic subtype, the so-called atopic eczema (AE). However, in up to 30% of patients with AD, there are normal serum IgE levels and negative skin tests; as a result, the term non-atopic eczema (NAE) has been proposed to replace the otherwise used terms intrinsic or non-IgE-associated form of AD. Facing this constellation, solely atopy patch tests, which elicit eczematous skin reactions after epidermal application of common aeroallergens, may indicate a putative role of local T cell response in the skin and, thus, are highly important in NAE. Next to a certain genetic disposition, infectious triggers and autoreactivity in patients with NAE have been observed. In the following, we will present a short overview to highlight typical characteristics in NAE and possible pathogenic factors in this AD subtype.

title: 14. Jahrestagung der Arbeitsgemeinschaft Pädiatrische Pneumologie und Allergologie (APPA)
Entwicklung und Evaluation eines visuellen Schnelltests zur Bestimmung von spezifischem IgE im Kapillarblut oder Heparinblut
authors: D. Runge; K.-P. Westpfahl-Wiesener; H A Schwertner
abstract: The number of allergic patients in industrialized countries has increased over the last 30 years. At present, approximately 30% of the European inhabitants have been affected. According to estimations, only a fraction of patients with respiratory allergy is diagnosed at an early stage and treated correctly. The European Academy for Allergology and Clinical Immunology (EAACI) has, therefore, initiated a campaign focusing on the early diagnosis of allergy. Early diagnosis needs easy screening instruments. Thus, an easy visual allergy test for the fast detection of specific IgE in capillary blood has been developed. This test is based on the ELISAtechnique (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) and adapted to be carried out at room temperature with a result within 30 minutes using only 2 -3 drops of whole blood (75 100 μl). Specific IgE for either 12 separate food allergens or 12 separate inhalation allergens can be tested in parallel in one test. The current allergen panel covers approximately 90% of the relevant inhalant allergens or food allergens for northern and middle Europe. Allergens on the membrane give a visible sign in the shape of a + for positive reactions and a - for negative reactions. Correlation of results of the fast allergy test with results of the Pharmacia CAP was shown. In 313 patients the test showed 96% positive and 98% negative correlation in average. In conclusion, the test represents a valid method for screening of elevated specific IgE for the most common inhalant and food allergens.

title: Systematisch erhöhte elterliche Nennung von Symptomen im Sinne einer Neurodermitis (overreporting) in Abhängigkeit zur Nähe zu Tierställen als einem vermuteten umweltbezogenen Risikofaktor
abstract: In Lower Saxony there has been ongoing discussion on potential health effects caused by emissions (bioaerosols) of livestock production facilities. We investigated the relationship between intensive livestock facilities in the neighborhood and respiratory, cutaneous or allergic diseases in 5- to 6-year-old children. Within a cross-sectional epidemiological study in 2001 a standardized questionnaire about respiratory and allergic symptoms and corresponding risk factors was used (n = 7,943). In addition, we examined flexural eczema. Individual exposition to bioaerosols coming from livestock facilities, for example endotoxin, was estimated on the basis of a Lagrangian simulation model of aerosol transport. For the investigation on overreporting with respect to dermatitis symptoms 3,374 observations were used. A probable overreporting was identified for the group of parents who did not live near livestock production facilities, but complained about agricultural odor annoyance. They reported twice as much skin symptoms (itchy skin condition during the last year 50.7% vs. 21.5 - 26.1% for the other groups), whereas the prevalence rate for visible signs of dermatitis hardly varies between the different strata of exposition (overall 5.8%). The homogeneity of odds ratios between.reported itchy skin condition and examined flexural eczema for the different strata is not fulfilled (p value < 0.05). Taking into account the odor annoyance, we have a strong hint for an overreporting of skin symptoms by a small study population group (3.2% of all), so that a general overreporting of allergic symptoms in this group can be assumed. Complementary objective medical examinations seem to be necessary to identify potential sources of bias even in case standardized questionnaires are used, particularly when issues of environmental health are dealt with.

title: Berufsbedingte allergische Alveolitiden
abstract: Extrinsic allergic alveolitis (hypersensitivity pneumonitis) due to occupation-related allergens may be difficult to be recognized because these allergic disorders are rare or even exotic. This article reviews and updatesthese occupational lung diseases.

title: Tagesschläfrigkeit bei saisonaler allergischer Rhinitis
authors: B. A. Stuck; J Czajkowski; Anna-Eva Hagner; Ludger Klimek; Joachim T. Maurer; Karl Hörmann; Thomas Verse
abstract: Apart from classical symptomes of allergy, seasonal allergic rhinitis is known to impair daytime performance and to increase daytime fatigue and sleepiness. These effects have not been evaluated systematically up to know.Aim of this study was to assess the impact of seasonal allergic rhinitis on daytime sleepiness measured with a validated questionnaire (Epworth Sleepiness Scale, ESS). Twenty-five patients with seasonal allergic rhinitis were compared to 25 healthy volunteers in a prospective controlled clinical trial. Daytime sleepiness and symptoms of allergic rhinitis (nasal obstruction and nasal itching. sneezing, conjunctivitis, and itching of the palate) were assessed with the ESS and a questionnaire before and during the pollen season 2002 and the severity of the disease was evaluated. Daytime sleepiness increased in the allergy group during the season (extrascasonal score: 6.8 ′ 2.7, intraseasonal score: 8.2 ′ 3.4) and remained unchanged in the controll group (extrascasonal score: 5.4 ′ 2.4, intraseasonal score: 5.3 ′ 2.4), leading to statistically significant between group differences (p < 0.05). The increase in daytime sleepiness was depending on the severity of the disease and was more pronounced in those patients with moderate-to-severe allergic rhinitis. Seasonal allergic rhinitis leads to an increased daytime sleepiness during the pollen season. Stasticially significant differences in daytime sleepiness can be assessed when comparing patients with healthy controls. The changes in daytime sleepiness were depending on the severity of the disease.

title: Allergene im Innenraum
abstract: We spend up to over 80% of the time indoors. The quality of indoor air is determined by different factors such as human transpiration, pollutants and especially indoor allergens and their influence on health. Indoor allergens may considerably effect our well-being and efficiency. They are seen to be a dominant cause of allergic disease such as asthma and eczema. Symptoms like headache, dizziness, poor concentration, fatigue as well as allergic reactions such as irritation of the eyes and the respiratory system are frequently related to indoor allergens. Mould and house dust mites are the predominant indoor allergens to cause allergic disease. The most important efforts to reduce indoor allergens are above all prevention and allergen avoidance.

title: Ein neues serologisches Screeningverfahren zur Diagnostik der Zimmerspringbrunnenalveolitis
authors: J. Sennekamp; Dirk Koschel; M. Rolke; D Müller-Wening
abstract: A new ELISA is presented here, which detects the IgG antibodies against the antigens in the moldy water of misting fountains. In the sera of 30 of 32 patients suffering from humidifier lung from these new developed humidifiers, IgG antibodies were detected by this screening test. Positive results of this ELISA using coated pooled moldy humidifier water from 4 patients should be confirmed by the Ouchterlony test using patients humidifier water or by IgG tests against the single antigens of humidifier lung as Aureobasidium pullulans, Cephalosporium acremonium, Penicillia and other known molds and bacteria.

title: Störungen der Zytotoxizität: Familiäre hämophagozytische Lymphohistiozytose
Zur umweltmedizinischen Bedeutung von persistierenden chlororganischen Verbindungen für Atemwege und Lungen
authors: M. Schulz; Holger Zimmer; Gerhard Triebig
abstract: The exposure to organochlorine chemicals of the general population may arise questions about potential health hazards. For an appropriate medical advice and systemic diagnostic procedure, knowledge about chemical properties, toxikokinetic characteristics as well as toxicity to humans is necessary. The purpose of this review is to present actual informations about the relevant substances, measures for diagnosis, therapy and prevention. On that occasion, inquiries about effects on the respiratory tract and lungs are considered, respectively.

title: Neue immunmodulierende Strategien bei der spezifischen Immuntherapie
authors: Joachim Saloga; Iris Bellinghausen; Bettina Klostermann; I. Böttcher; J. Knop
abstract: Atopic/allergic diseases are characterized by exaggerated, at least initially Th2-dominated immune responses against allergens. Therefore it must be the aim of an immunologically based therapy to inhibit and to correct these immune responses qualitatively. Both aspects can already be achieved by conventional specific immunotherapy, but the effect may be enhanced by new adjuvants and allergen preparations, eventually in combination with biologicals and reprogrammed autologous immune cells.

title: Störungen des T-Zellrezeptors und der primären Signaltransduktion
authors: V. Wahn; K. Schwarz; H. J. Girschick; W. Friedrich

title: Intrinsic Asthma  Schlüssel zum Verständnis des allergischen Asthmas?
abstract: Until today, the pathogenesis of intrinsic asthma has been incompletely understood. Only few investigations have systematically compared the immunology of intrinsic asthma with allergic asthma. Only a very small number ofstudies have been able to find differences between allergic and intrinsic asthma. Intrinsic asthma, which differs markedly from allergic asthma of children and adolescence, might be related to a chronic T lymphocyte activation possibly due to an endogenous antigen. In addition, cytotoxic mechanisms similar to other autoimmune diseases might play a role. Understanding intrinsic asthma might hold the key to the understanding of chronic allergic asthma and its underlying inflammation leading to persistent airflow limitation and airway remodeling.

title: X-chromosomale lymphoproliferative Erkrankung (XLP)
Die lokale Immunantwort der Tonsilla palatina  Unterschiede in der Verteilung und Expression von IgA+-Plasmazellen bei Bet v 1-allergischen und nicht allergischen Patienten
authors: H. Olze; L. Morawietz; Carmela De Meco; G. Achatz; Elke Luger
abstract: Background: The position of the tonsils which belong to the mucosa-associated lymphoid tissues (MALT), implies a key role as secondary lymphoid organ in initiating immune responses against various antigens. While the IgE antibody-mediated release of mediators constitutes the immunopathological basis for immediate symptoms, much less is known concerning the role of allergen-specific responses of isotypes other than IgE. In order to investigate the impact of an allergen-specific immune reaction on the local immune response in palatine tonsils, the expression of IgA + plasma cells and the distribution of proliferating cells in Bet v 1-(Betula verrucosa 1) allergic and non-allergic patients were detected. Methods: Using immunohistological methods, IgA + plasma cells and K167 + cells were stained in cryosections of tonsils from 20 patients according to chronic tonsillitis (Bet v 1-allergic/non-allergic patients, n = 10). The distribution of IgA + plasma- and Ki67 + -proliferating cells was analyzed. Results: Our analyses showed a differential distribution and a significantly (p < 0.01) diminished expression of IgA + plasma cells in tonsils of Bet v 1-allergic patients compared to non-allergic patients. Further, tonsils of allergic and non-allergic patients did not show differences in the distribution of proliferating cells. However, tonsils of both investigated groups were comparable concerning their number and size of secondary lymphoid follicles and their morphologic structures. Conclusions: Altogether, these data may lead to the assumption that the reduction of IgA + plasma cells within the epithelial microenvironment of the crypts and the extrafollicular areas in allergic individuals results in a reduced ability to mount a protective immune response against allergens. The comparable number and size of follicles and the distribution of proliferating cells in the tonsillar germinal centers may reflect the ongoing germinal center reaction.

title: Kälteurtikaria: Untersuchung zu Ursachen, Therapie und Verlauf
abstract: Cold urticaria is a disease which after contact to cold objects, fluids and air can lead to wheals in lighter and shock reactions in more severe cases. Diagnostically, many different clinical and serological tests have been reported to secure the diagnosis and possible causes. Therapeutical approaches include antihistamines and cold tolerance induction baths amongst other options. The main objectives of the present study were to evaluate a wide range of diagnostic data, to compare different treatment measures and to follow-up clinical symptoms and therapeutic success within a large group of patients. 82 patients, 46 with an isolated cold urticaria and 36 with other additional factors of wheal formation were examined and followed-up 1 - 20 years later by questionnaire. With a median age of onset at 20 years, the disease duration was 1 year in spontaneously healed and 15 years in still affected patients. The mean border temperature below which wheals developed was 22 °C before and 17 °C after therapy. No statistically relevant abnormalities were discovered in serological and hematological examinations. Isolated infectious hearths were rarely found, particularly in consiliary ear-nose-throat examinations. Whereas 52% of patients treated with cetirizine (12 out of 23 patients) reported a significant improvement of their symptoms, no patient who had undergone a therapy with cold water baths continued this for longer than 1 year due to limited effects and gross inconvenience. This study underlines the clinical dilemma of cold urticaria that, despite a defined physical provocation factor, the etiopathogenic as well as therapeutic knowledge are still limited until today. Furthermore, the results of these examinations of diverse parameters in a large and well-characterized patient group show that elaborate diagnostic testing makes sense only if individually fitted and after thorough history taking. Intensive and long-term care of these patients is mandatory.

title: Prospektive pathomorphologische, immunologische und mykologische Untersuchungen zur chronischen Pilzsinusitis
authors: A. May; C. Lehne; Ellen Lambrecht; R Enzensberger; Volker Brade; Wolfgang Gstöttner; A. Weber
abstract: Chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) is a disease very frequently encountered by otorhinolaryngologists. According to Ponikau et al. fungi are accused to trigger eosinophilic CRS. Other authors quote fungi to cause CRS in only upto 10%. In Germany, data concerning fungal rhinosinusitis in CRS patients are rare. Therefore, a study on 51 patients with CRS and 10 controls was conducted. Nasal mucus was collected by cotton sponges (group A, n = 39) or by flushing the nose (group B, n = 12), the controls were treated respectively. Nasal secretions were processed for microbiology, fungal cultivation and cytology. Fungi and eosinophiles were visualised by microscopic study of smears in Pappenheim and Grocott. Skin prick tests and specific IgE measurements were done to evaluate an atopy. Five (12%) patients in group A and 1 patient (8%) in group B had positive fungal cultures. Altogether, from 6 (12%) patients with CRS and 2 controls fungi were cultivated. The species identified were Aspergillus, Alternaria, Aureobasidium, Candida, Cladosporium, Penicillium. Fourteen (36%) patients in group A and 2 (16%) in group B showed fungi on microscopic examination. So, in 16 (31%) patients with CRS fungi were found in the cytological preparations, 1 control was positive. In 3 patients, skin prick tests and specific antigen against fungi correlated with the microscopic and mycological findings. Our data indicate that allergic fungal rhinosinusitis can occur in 6% of CRS. In 31% of CRS fungi were found in nasal mucus. If in such patients conventional treatment fails, new therapeutic strategies could be of relevance.

title: Entzündungsformen der chronischen Rhinosinusitis
authors: Frank B. Sachse; Sabine Jörg; Claudia Rudack
abstract: Objective and design: Etiology and classification of chronic rhinosinusitis still remain unclear. Chronic rhinosinusitis can be differentiated clinically according to the presence or absence of nasal polyps in the nasal cavity. Knowledge of infiltrating leukocytes in these 2 sinusitis entities is still limited. Therefore, based on quantification of inflammatory cells in biopsies from patients with nasal polyposis and chronic rhinosinusitis without nasal polyps, we tried to answer the question if there is need for further subclassification of chronic rhinosinusitis into different disease entities. Patients and methods: Nasal polyps (n = 37) and tissue from patients suffering from chronic sinusitis without polyps (n=41) were examined by light microscopy after immunostaining with monoclonal antibodies against eosinophilic cationic protein (eosinophilic granulocytes), neutrophilic elastase (neutrophilic granulocytes) and CD38 antigen which is expressed by a variety of cells including plasma cells and activated T lymphocytes. All data were tested using a Mann-Whitney U-test. Results: In nasal polyposis, we found a significant increase of eosinophils and neutrophils (p < 0,05) compared to chronic nonpolypous rhinosinusitis. Samples of chronic nonpolypous rhinosinusitis were dominated by neutrophils. In addition, a considerable infiltration of CD38-positive cells around mucosal gland cells was observed in chronic rhinosinusitis but not in nasal polyposis. Conclusions: Different types and quantities of inflammatory cells support our hypothesis that there is need for further subclassification of chronic rhinosinusitis according to polypous and nonpolypous.

title: Antihistaminika und Regresse  der Höhepunkt der Unwirtschaftlichkeit und Unwissenschaftlichkeit
Pharmakologische Therapie der Polyposis nasi
abstract: Nasal polyposis affects nearly 4% of the overall population in western countries, and presents a real challenge to the physician due to its severity, chronicity and recurrence rate. Characteristic histomorphological features of polyps are an eosinophilic inflammation and the destruction of connective tissue, and recent research focused on cytokines, chemokines, growth factors and metalloproteinases to explain these features, as the etiology of nasal polyposis remains largely unclear. Currently, topical and systemic glucocorticosteroids are first-choice drug therapy approaches, and good evidence from controlled trials is available for topical, but not for systemic steroid therapy. Surgery is indicated if adequate drug treatment fails, which often needs to be maintained for months or years after surgery. Limited experience exists for other drugs, such as antihistamines, antileucotrienes and furosemid, which may be added in selected cases. Aspirin desensitization may be a therapeutic option for patients who do not respond to corticosteroids nor surgery. Recently, antibiotics such as macrolides have been suggested to have therapeutic activity based on their anti-inflammatory properties, but large-scale controlled trials are lacking. New approaches have currently evolved, specifically targeting eosinophilic recruitment (anti-CCR3, anti-eotaxin) and inflammation (anti-lL-4,5,13), IgE antibodies (anti-IgE) or tissue remodeling, reducing the activity of metalloproteinases. This review summarizes current knowledge on pathomechanisms as well as established and future approaches in the pharmacological management of bilateral eosinophilic nasal polyposis.

title: Acrolein im Zigarettenrauch  ein Inhibitor der EAA?
Zink und Kupfer in Serum und induziertem Sputum von Patienten mit allergischer Rhinitis und allergischem Asthma
authors: Vesna Djuric; D. Djarmati; Gordana Djordjevic-Denic; Vesna Tomić-Spirić; Aleksandra Perić‐Popadić; J. Sojic; Sanvila Rašković; M Bogić
abstract: Background: Zinc was shown to have protective effect on the respiratory system, so it may play a role in allergic airway diseases. The aim of our study was to measure zinc and copper levels in serum and induced sputum in patients with allergic rhinitis and patients with allergic asthma. Methods: We measured concentrations of zinc and copper in serum and in supernatant of induced sputum in 21 patients with allergic asthma, in 13 patients with allergic rhinitis and in 10 control subjects. Results: We have found decreased levels of zinc in serum of patients with allergic asthma and in patients with allergic rhinitis. Furthermore, levels of zinc in serum in patients with allergic asthma were lower than in patients with allergic rhinitis. Concentrations of zinc in supernatant of induced sputum were lower in asthmatics than in control subjects and rhinitics, but this difference was not statistically significant. There was no significant difference in concentrations of copper in serum and in sputum between asthmatics, rhinitics and control subjects. We have also found a positive linear correlation between zinc concentrations in serum and sputum in the group of control subjects, in patients with allergic asthma and in male patients with allergic rhinitis. Conclusion: We conclude that zinc deficiency was confirmed both in patients with allergic asthma and in patients with allergic rhinitis.

title: Unethische „Empfehlungen“ der KVen und der KBV zur Therapie der allergischen Rhinitis: Wider das ärztliche Gewissen
Stufentherapie des atopischen Ekzems im Kindesalter
abstract: Atopic eczema is one of the most common chronic diseases in childhood with a cumulative prevalence of 20%. As a complex genetic disease, it is characterized by altered epidermal keratinization pathways, impairment of skin barrier function, and immunoregulatory imbalance resulting in acute or chronic skin inflammation. Affected patients and their families are severely restricted in their quality of life because of a chronic relapsing illness and high costs of therapy. They depend upon an efficient, stage-adapted treatment with the lowest possible rate of unwanted side effects. This review summarizes topical and systemic options in the management of atopic eczema. In particular, local antiinflammatory treatment with topical corticosteroids is reviewed with a special emphasis on preparations possessing a high therapeutic index. Additionally, the role of topical immunomodulators (tacrolimus, pimecrolimus) is critically evaluated with regard to the safety profile and therapeutic efficacy of these substances in the pediatric age group. Systemic treatment options comprising antihistamines, antibiotics, corticosteorids, UV therapy and cyclosporin A are also extensively discussed.

title: Pharmakologische und klinische Eigenschaften von Desloratadin vs. Loratadin: eine evidenzbasierte Differenzierung
abstract: Although head-to-head comparative studies between desloratadine and loratadine are lacking, a comparison of efficacy is possible based on evidence from the literature. Pharmacology, pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetik data point to desloratadine as superior compound in terms of efficacy and safety, which translates into a stronger anti-obstructive effect and a better quality of life. Both of these effects are of clinical relevance to the patients.

title: Störungen der Granulozyten- (Phagozyten) Funktion
authors: V. Wahn; Joachim Roesler; Reinhard Seger
abstract: Granulozyten sind Teil des nicht adaptiven zellularen Immunsystems. Storungen der Funktion dieser Zellen konnen klinisch ebenso schwere Konsequenzen haben wie deren Abwesenheit hervorrufen. Die wichtigsten funktionellen Storungen entstehen durch das Fehlen wichtiger Adhasionsproteine sowie durch Storungen der Produktion mikrobizider Sauerstoffmetabolite. Daneben sind weitere genetische Storungen bekannt, fur die auf Spezialliteratur verwiesen wird [6, 7, 12, 13]. Zunachst zu den Adhasionsproteindefekten.

title: Leugnung von Allergenkontakt bei Vogelhalterlunge
Wiederholte Unverträglichkeitsreaktionen auf Lokalanästhetika  gibt es eine Erklärung?
authors: F. Jeger; Werner J. Pichler; Arthur Helbling
abstract: Intolerance reactions to local anesthetics are frequent complications in medical and dental offices, but true allergy to local anesthetics is very rare (< 1%). In this study, we aimed to characterize patients with recurrent - at least 2 - intolerance reactions to local anesthetics. All patients had negative skin tests to local anesthetics of the immediate (IgE-mediated) as well as of the delayed type (T cell-mediated), and all have been subcutaneously challenged with a local anesthetic. During the last 10 years, out of 477 patients with a history of intolerance reactions to local anaesthetics referred to us, 275 of them have been thoroughly tested for allergy, particularly to local anesthetics. Of 43 eligible patients, 36 could be interviewed and 23 of them agreed to new tests. Although many of the study patients experienced symptoms suggestive for a vagovasal reaction, they seemed not to have an overall higher tendency for psychovegetative dispositions. The clinical reaction of intolerance following local anesthetics was always of the same pattern. There was no evidence of an enhanced mast-cell releasability or tissue reactivity to specific and non-specific mast-cell stimulants, respectively, and basal serum tryptase level was within the normal range. Moreover, a negative challenge test with local anesthetics is no guarantee for recurrence of intolerance reactions to local anesthetics. Nevertheless, we are in agreement with the recommendation of other groups to do challenge tests in the diagnostic of intolerance reactions to local anesthetics. Based on our results, we consider pharmacological effects as the most likely explanation in subjects with recurrent episodes to local anesthetics resembling allergy. In contrast to allergy to local anesthetics, all patients recovered spontaneously within 30 minutes without any therapy.

title: 12. Bad Saarower Herbsttagung des Verbandes der Allergologen Brandenburgs e.V. mit Arzthelferinnenseminar
Die Rolle von dendritischen Zellen bei der Induktion und Modulation der allergischen Immunantwort
authors: Iris Bellinghausen; Bettina König; Ingo Böttcher; J. Knop; Joachim Saloga
abstract: Dendritic cells (DC) are the most potent antigen-presenting cells and therefore also play a key role in the initiation of allergic immune responses underlying atopic/allergic diseases like allergic bronchial asthma, allergic rhinokonjunctivits and atopic eczema. Due to their potency in presentation of antigens to T cells, they also are appealing candidates for antigen-specific immunotherapeutical approaches. Exposure of immature DC derived from peripheral blood monocytes of allergic donors to allergen proteins leads to early activation, i.e. phosphorylation, of STAT6 followed by (low) production of IL-13. IL-13 enhances STAT6 phosphorylation in autologous T cells and the production of the Th2 cytokines IL-4 and IL-5, but not of the Th 1 cytokine IFN-γ in vitro. The inducible costimulatory molecule ICOS which is induced after T cell activation and its ligand (ICOSL) being expressed on monocytes and DC, also plays an important role in the regulation of Th2 effector cells. Immature DC pulsed with allergen and arrested in their immature state by IL-10 induce anergy in cocultured autologous T cells associated with production of IL-10. These T cells also exhibit regulatory functions inhibiting the proliferation and cytokine production of other T cells. DC can also be transfected very efficiently with allergen DNA using adenoviral vectors. These transfected DC activate predominantly CD8 + T cells and induce IFN-γ production also in CD4 + T cells, together with enhanced IL-10 production. These data support the key importance of DC for the development of atopic/allergic diseases and indicate that DC may be useful tools for antigen-specific immunointervention.

title: Ernährungsberatung und diätetische Maßnahmen bei chronischer Urtikaria
authors: Richard B. Kurzel; C. Behr-Völtzer; C. Zick; R. Weßbecher
abstract: Chronic urticaria is a frequent dermatological disease. Food allergy or intolerance are often suspected as the cause of urticaria symptoms. IgE-mediated food allergies are normally not relevant but pseudoallergic reactions to food additives and possibly biogenic amines may be crucial. Therefore, lots of patients presenting in an outpatient clinic kept diets that were worthless and that could lead to nutritional defiency in the long run. A structured schedule in the diagnostic procedure might be helpful and necessary in respecting the relationship to foods. This article especially focuses on additives in nutrition, clinical relevance of elimination diets and the importance of that dietary measure. Hereby, the procedure of dietary diagnostics and advice by the specialist in trophology is presented in detail on the base of national and international position papers and our own experiences of investigations, collected from our specialized outpatient clinic for chronic urticaria at the unit of allergy and environment, department of dermatology at the University Hospital Hamburg-Eppendorf. Besides, the results demonstrate that a close cooperation between allergologists and a specialist in trophology is constructive to rule out or confirm food allergy, respectively, intolerance and to avoid keeping unnecessary diets.

title: Chemische Substanzen und Kontaktallergie  eine Bewertung von 244 Substanzen
authors: Eva Schlede; W. Aberer; T. Fuchs; I. Gerner; Holger Lessmann; Tobias Maurer; R. Rossbacher; G. Stropp; E. Wagner; D. Kayser
abstract: Between 1985 and 2001 a panel of 30 experts (dermatologists and chemical scientist from university, industry and federal offices) evaluated the allergenic potential of 244 chemical substances or chemicals identified as ingredients of natural products. The evaluation process was based on published evidence regarding effects on man, experimental studies, and structure-activity considerations. Category A comprised significant contact allergens. Chemicals for which reliable reports regarding sensitizing properties or cross-reactivity were available were ranked in group B, whereas chemicals with doubtful sensitizing properties and insignificant allergens were classified as C. The tabulated review comprises 98 substances of category A, 77 ofB and 69 of grade C.

title: ECP (eosinophil cationic protein) in der pulmologischen Praxis
authors: Gottfried von Kirchbach; V. Ebert; R. M. Krause; R. Wahl
abstract: ECP is one of the most prominent protein mediators from activated eosinophils. Although the diagnostic value of the test has been discussed controversially, our research has shown its diagnostic importance, e.g. in the disease process of asthma and other diseases. The Allergophanna ECP Test is easy to use - all incubation steps are performed at room temperature - and can easily be integrated into daily laboratory routine.

title: Wirkung von Cetirizin und Fluticasonpropionat- Nasenspray auf Symptome und Entzündungsmediatoren der saisonalen allergischen Rhinitis
authors: Keith Dahl; Bernd Lange; Gabriële Holtappels; K.‐F. Lukat; C. Bachert
abstract: Antihistamines and topical corticosteroids represent the established first-line therapy of allergic rhinitis. We compared the effects of oral cetirizine versus fluticasone propionate nasal spray on symptoms and concentrations of inflammatory mediators in nasal secretions of patients with seasonal allergic rhinitis during the pollen season. In a randomized double-blind study, 30 patients with birch and grass allergy received either 10 mg cetirizine p.o. (CET) and a placebo nasal spray or 200 μg fluticasone propionate nasal spray (FP) and a placebo tablet OD for ca. 4.5 months covering the birch and grass pollen season. Daily nasal and eye symptoms were registered using a diary card and were analyzed under consideration of daily pollen load. Nasal secretion was collected by the filter paper-disc method and concentrations of histamine and ECP were measured by ELISA. Regarding the total symptom score made up of nasal and eye symptoms throughout the study, no significant difference between the 2 patient groups was found. In contrast, the analysis of the total nasal symptom score (TNSS) showed significantly better results for the FP group in the course of the season, if only days with a pollen count > 20/m 3 were evaluated (p = 0.0197). Cetirizine, on the other hand, showed a clear tendency to stronger effects on eye symptoms using the same method of evaluation (p = 0.0584). Concentrations of histamine and ECP in nasal secretions were significantly lower under medication with FP. The study demonstrates that by separately analyzing nasal and ocular symptoms under consideration of the intensity of the pollen flight a more differentiated assessment of the effects of anti-SAR medications is possible. Especially in regions characterized by a rather fluctuating pollen flight, evaluation only of those days with high pollen load may yield an essential gain of information. The results on liberation of inflammatory mediators confirmed the greater anti-inflammatory effect of the topical glucocorticosteroid. It can be suggested that a combination of the 2 therapeutic principles is reasonable for subjects with moderate to severe nasal and ocular symptoms.

title: Feinstaub(PM10)- und Pollenbelastung im Winter und ihre Abhängigkeit von der Wetterlage
abstract: Particulate matter (PM) is the general term used for a mixture of solid particles and liquid droplets found in the air. These particles, which come in a wide range of sizes (fine particles are less than 2.5 μm in diameter and coarser-size particles are larger than 2.5 μm), originating from many different stationary and mobile sources as well as from natural sources. Fine particles result from fuel combustion from motor vehicles, power generation and industrial facilities as well as from residential fireplaces and wood stoves. Coarse particles (PM10) are generally emitted from sources, such as vehicles traveling on unpaved roads, materials handling and crushing and grinding operations, as well as windblown dust. Inhalable PM includes both fine and coarse particles. These particles can accumulate in the respiratory system and are associated with numerous health effects. Exposure to coarse particles is primarily associated with the aggravation of respiratory conditions, such as asthma. Fine particles are most closely associated with such health effects like increased hospital admissions and emergency room visits for heart and lung disease, increased respiratory symptoms and disease, decreased lung function, and even premature death. Sensitive groups that appear to be at greatest risk to such effects include the elderly, individuals with cardiopulmonary disease such as asthma, and children. This study investigates PM10 and airborne pollen during different years and shows connections between weather conditions in winter time and these particles.

title: Rechtsgutachten:Zur Befugnis der Kassenärztlichen Bundesvereinigung und der Kassenärztlichen Vereinigungen, Empfehlungen zur Therapie der allergischen Rhinitis zu erlassen, die den medizinisch begründeten Leitlinien widersprechen
authors: Chr. Koenig; Klaus Hentschel; F. Meurer

title: Die Pathophysiologie des Nies- und Juckreizes bei der allergischen Rhinitis
authors: Oliver Pfaar; Thomas Hummel; Ludger Klimek
abstract: Apart from nasal obstruction and rhinorrhea, itching and sneezing are main symptoms of allergic rhinitis. Apparently, activation of the central nervous system plays a major role in the pathophysiology of this process. It is known that itching and sneezing are primarily mediated by the trigeminal system. The afferent trigeminal fibers are composed of myelated Aδ fibers and thin, non-myelated C fibers which are activated by polymodal nociceptors. Furthermore, there is strong evidence in animal-experimental studies showing that afferent trigeminal C fibers participate in the local by liberating neuropeptides, e.g. substance P (SP) or calcitonine gene-related peptide (CGRP) (concept of the neurogenic inflammation). These neurotransmitters themselves have a potential effect on the allergic cascade and may modulate the immunologic response. The knowledge of these interactions could explain the role of the psychological impact in the inflammatory process of allergic rhinitis and asthma. The present paper describes the (micro-) anatomy and the nasal innervation under normal conditions and shows an overview about the activation of itching and sneezing via the trigeminal system. In addition, the possible effects of this trigeminal activation on the local process via neuropeptides, e.g. SP and CGRP, are discussed. It might be hypothesized that in the future the modulation of these neuropeptides due to the neurogenic inflammation might become one possible clue in treatment of atopy diseases.

title: Antihistaminika in der Dermatologie*
abstract: Urticaria including chronic urticaria, allergic rhinitis, allergic conjunctivitis, mastocytosis, prevention of allergic reactions including idiopathic anaphylaxis, food allergy, insect venom allergy, radiocontrastmedia intolerance are indications for antihistamines. There are many side effects in particular with antihistamines of the first generation due to their CNS-effects, therefore these antihistaminines should be prescribed with great caution in patients who use to drive cars, who must be alert during their job and elder patients. The antihistamines of the second generation are advantegous in all these cases and in addition their effectiveness has been proven in most cases in by far better clinical studies than the old one.

title: Die Hypereosinophilie-Syndrome
authors: Dagmar Simon; L. R. Braathen; Hans‐Uwe Simon
abstract: Hypereosinophilic syndromes (HES) comprise a heterogeneous group of uncommon diseases that are characterized by peripheral blood eosinophilia (> 1,500/mm 3 ; > 1.5 G/l), as well as tissue eosinophilia associated with organ dysfunction without other identifiable causes such as allergic diseases, drug hypersensitivity, infections, tumors or lymphomas. By means of modern diagnostic tools including immunologic and molecular methods, 2 main subgroups of HES, the myeloproliferative and lymphocytic variants, have been identified in the last decade. In addition, HES include the familial variant, the episodic type, the benign asymptomatic blood eosinophilia as well as disorders with blood eosinophilia and single organ involvement. Several complex disorders although fulfilling the criteria of HES, e.g. Churg-Strauss syndrome, are still considered as separate entities. Therapeutic options are corticosteroids, but also immunomodulators, cytostatic agents, monoclonal antibodies as well as bone marrow transplantation. Recently, the description of the HES-causing fusion gene FIP1L1-PDGFRA coding a tyrosine kinase gained attention because these patients respond to the tyrosine kinase inhibitor imatinib. In this review, we discuss current concepts of the classification, diagnostic procedures and therapy of HES.

title: Klinisch-ökonomische Evaluation von Epikutantests bei putativer dentaler Werkstoffunverträglichkeit
authors: Christine Baulig; R. Schieferdecker; Mirosław Dziuk; Frank Krummenauer
abstract: Background: Putative and symptomatic allergies towards dental materials are an issue of increasing relevance in the context of dental-prosthetic treatments. Allergy passport information enables dentists to decide about certain dental materials; however, this decision process calls for sensitive consideration of validity and clinical relevance of the information provided by the allergy passport and the underlying epicutaneous tests. Materials and methods: In order to evaluate dentists' recommendations for individual dental materials when the results of epicutaneous tests are involved, the data of 83 patients were analyzed whose cost-funding applications were based on epicutaneous test results. Furthermore, the performance quality and the validity of interpretations concerning the choice of dental materials based on these tests were evaluated both from a clinical and a health-economic point of view. An interdisciplinary expert panel rated the validity of the test and its suitability for the decision process at hand. Based on the clinical data, the panel derived a recommendation for an appropriate and cost-efficient dental supplementation. The cost estimates for these recommendations were compared to the dentists' treatment and cost proposals in order to characterize the financial damage of material recommendations based on incorrect applications or interpretations of epicutaneous tests. Results: Epicutaneous testing is indicated only for manifest symptoms which were present in 8% of the analyzed cases. 66 of 83 cases could present an allergy passport; however, the results of the epicutaneous tests were stated correctly in these allergy passports for only 70% of these 66 cases. Furthermore, the clinical relevance of the test results was only documented in 3 of these 66 allergy passports. Only 10 of the 83 suggested material changes could be confirmed by the expert panel, for 42 patients (51%) a more suitable and cost-efficient supplementation was suggested. The submitted cost-funding applications exceeded the recalculation of the expert panel in median by 680 Euro (interquartile range: 297 - 1,966 Euro). The total cost deviation for the 83 patients amounted to 113,186 Euro, mainly due to the rather large fraction (65%) of applications intending a prosthetic restoration made of gold. Conclusion: The results of the present examination demonstrate the limited suitability of allergy passports as a tool in dental decision making with respect to the selection of dental materials. Nevertheless, allergy passports are often used rather uncritically by dentists as a legitimation for material changes, which may result in both clinically and economically relevant consequences.

title: Prävalenz, Klassifikation und Wahrnehmung der allergischen und nicht-allergischen Rhinitis
abstract: Background: Allergic rhinitis (AR) and non-infectious, non-allergic rhinitis (NINA), are common disorders which may prompt patients to seek medical help. Methods: We performed a survey in a representative sample of the Belgian population (n = 4,959) with an overall prevalence of self-declared recent rhinitis symptoms of 39.3%. Detailed information on patients having experienced nasal symptoms over the past year was then obtained from a random sample of respondents (n = 743). Results: The adjusted prevalence was 29.8% for AR and 9.6% for NINA, respectively. According to the ARIA classification, there was significantly more persistent symptomatology in the AR group (40.8%) than in NINA (23.5%) (p < 0.001), and more moderate/severe symptom intensity in AR (75.4%) than in NINA (5 3.1%) (p < 0.001). AR patients suffered from a greater number of symptoms than did NINA patients (p < 0.001). Asthma, skin and food allergy as comorbidities were all found to be significantly more prevalent in the AR vs. the NINA group (p < 0.05 for all). The percentage of consulting patients (total: 66.8%) who subjectively perceived their rhinitis as moderate/severe, was 94.0%, whereas 75.6% of these patients were classified accordingly based on ARIA criteria. Conclusions: We found a high prevalence of self-declared rhinitis symptoms in the Belgian population, AR being about 3 times more prevalent than NINA. In addition, AR patients suffered from a greater number of symptoms and displayed a more persistent and moderate-severe ARIA profile than NINA. About 75% of patients in total, and about 82% seeking medical help, suffer from moderate to severe forms of allergic rhinitis.

title: TNF-alpha-Serumkonzentrationen nach einer spezifischen Provokation bei exogen-allergischer Alveolitis und bei organic dust toxic syndrome
authors: G Olbrich; Daniel Drömann; Dirk Koschel; D Müller-Wening; P. Zabel

title: Hyper-IgM-Syndrom
Blut-Leukozyten bei allergischen bronchopulmonalen Mykosen unter besonderer Berücksichtigung einer antimykotischen Therapie mit Itraconazol
authors: M. Kühr; A. aufm Kampe; Uwe R. Juergens

title: Die allergische Rhinitis: Besonderheiten von Diagnostik und Therapie im Kindes- und Jugendalter
abstract: Allergic rhinitis (AR) has a life prevalence of about 24% and, thereby, AR is the most common immune disease and one of the most common chronic diseases. It often develops in childhood or adolescence and there is a continuing trend towards increasing numbers in most industrialized countries in this age group, thus, diagnosis and therapy are of major importance. AR has a high impact on social living, school performance and mental and physical development of those children. In addition, it is accompanied by comorbidities such as conjunctivitis, bronchial asthma, food allergies, atopic dermatitis, sinusitis and others. E.g., the risk to develop bronchial asthma is approximately 4 times higher in children with AR if compared with a matched control group. In the drug treatment of AR, α-sympathomimetics, anticholinergic agents, nasal rinsing methods, topical and systemic antihistamines, topical glucocorticosteroids, and leukotrien rezeptorantagonists are used. Spezific immuntherapy (hyposensitization) is the only causal treatment option in AR besides allergen avoidance and should be used early in disease. Efficacy of subcutaneous immuntherapy is well-documented. Besides therapy, the efficiacy of specific immunotherapy to prevent new sensitizations and to avoid the allergic march should be taken into account.

title: „Allergie und Ohr“ – ein kurzes Editorial zu dieser Ausgabe

title: Biomarker bei der Allergen-Immuntherapie – ein EAACI Positionspapier
authors: Constanze A. Jakwerth; Mohamed H. Shamji; Jasper H. Kappen; Mübeccel Akdiş; Erika Jensen‐Jarolim; Edward F. Knol; Jrg Kleine Tebbe; Barbara Bohle; Adam Chaker; Stephen J. Till; Rudolf Valenta; Lars K. Poulsen; Moisés A. Calderón; Pascal Demoly; Oliver Pfaar; Lars Jacobsen; S.R. Durham; Carsten B. Schmidt‐Weber
abstract: Background: Allergen immunotherapy (AIT) is an effective treatment for allergic rhinoconjunctivitis (AR) with or without asthma. It is important to note that due to the complex interaction between patient, allergy triggers, symptomatology and vaccines used for AIT, some patients do not respond optimally to the treatment. Furthermore, there are no validated or generally accepted candidate biomarkers that are predictive of the clinical response to AIT. Clinical management of patients receiving AIT and efficacy in randomized controlled trials for drug development could be enhanced by predictive biomarkers. Method: The EAACI taskforce reviewed all candidate biomarkers used in clinical trials of AR patients with and without asthma in a literature review. Biomarkers were grouped into seven domains: (i) IgE (total IgE, specific IgE, and sIgE/Total IgE ratio), (ii) IgG-subclasses (sIgG1, sIgG4 including SIgE/ IgG4 ratio), (iii) Serum inhibitory activity for IgE (IgE-FAB and IgE-BF), (iv) Basophil activation, (v) Cytokines and Chemokines, (vi) Cellular markers (T regulatory cells, B regulatory cells, and dendritic cells) and (vii) In vivo biomarkers (including provocation tests). Results: All biomarkers were reviewed in the light of their potential advantages as well as their respective drawbacks. Unmet needs and specific recommendations on all seven domains were addressed. Conclusions: It is recommended to explore the use of allergen-specific IgG4 as a biomarker for compliance. sIgE/tIgE and IgE-FAB are considered as potential surrogate candidate biomarkers. Cytokine/chemokines and cellular reponses provided insight into the mechanisms of AIT. More studies for confirmation and interpretation of the possible association with the clinical response to AIT are needed.

Biologika in der Behandlung der chronischen Rhinosinusitis mit Nasenpolypen – Aktueller Stand
abstract: In 2006 to 2017, a number of randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trials on the use of monoclonal antibodies in chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps were published. They were the first to demonstrate that these innovative therapies are in principle effective in the treatment of nasal polyps. The target proteins, interleukin (IL)-4, IL-5, and IL-13 as well as immunoglobulin (Ig) E had been identified as key proteins in previous basic studies. The studies are characterized by small numbers of cases, but have paved the way for phase 3 studies, which are currently underway and which could lead to the market introduction of the first drug with this indication as early as next year. They already provide some hints of the effects to be expected from biologics; however, phase 3 studies with more patients and a more homogeneous patient population will be crucial for indications, patient selection, and stop rules for each of these biologics. For those patients with severe polyposis whose disease could previously not be controlled by pharmacotherapy and/or surgery, there will undoubtedly be new therapeutic options that will put an end to the risks and shortcomings of previous therapies.
